column1: Will Pedro Castillo cease to be the president of the Peru before 1 January 2024?

column6: only if he starts a war
He is very inexperienced. He has no support base in parliament to speak off. Peru is badly organised for stable government.

If there was an election tomorrow then he would undoubtedly lose, but the next election is not due until 2026. So some other mechanism of removal is needed. It seems unlikely that he will resign, but with 6 criminal cases running against him, a tiny minority of Congress supporting him and mass protests, impeachment does seem quite likely.

Extremely conservative institutions provide limited support inside of Peru for Castillo. I am not more confident due to timeline and also possibility of other countries in the Americas providing support to his administration.
4 out of former 7 Peruvian presidents (57%) had similar term length or shorter than implied in the question. That makes my base probability.

In the past 7 years, Peru has elected five presidents, coupled with the fact there are protests and riots demanding his resignation. With the global economy also at risk of declining, I could see further pressure coming forth for Castillo. But I take caution because the closing date is still shy of the seven-year average. Only maintaining a 55% because the protests are already here.
